items.title: name 'UnrecognizedMSGTypeError' is not defined

labels.name: Fixed?
labels.description: We believe this issue has been fixed. If still open, we are awaiting confirmation from issue creator

items.body:
**Bug Metadata**
* Version of extract_msg: [0.25.1]
* Your python version: Python [v3.7.0:1bf9cc5093]
* How did you launch extract_msg?
  -  I used the extract_msg package from a .py file

**Describe the bug**
We are using your library because we need to extract information from a .msg file which is arriving our systems within a .zip file in out Outlook mailbox.
In the process we extract the .msg to a local path and before calling your library we check the file exists, in some cases we get the following exception when calling your library: 

name 'UnrecognizedMSGTypeError' is not defined

If you need me to modify some setting from your library to provide more verbose logs I can reproduce the error again, please let me know. Thanks in advance

**What code did you use or can we use to reproduce this error?

```
 if os.path.isfile(msgPath):
	msg = None
	try:
		import extract_msg
		msg = extract_msg.openMsg(msgFilePath)
	except Exception as msgEx:
		Logger.error('{}Could not get msg object from msgFilePath. Exception was: {}'.format(strSpaces,msgEx))
		return
```
Is there a message.msg file you want to share to help us reproduce this?
- I need to speak to the Company Policy group  but unfortunately by default the don't allow us to share information out of our company, so I can't add here the .msg file.

**Traceback**
```
2020-07-31 19:31:42,880 ERROR    Could not get msg object from msgFilePath. Exception was: name 'UnrecognizedMSGTypeError' is not defined
```

**Screenshots**
None

**Additional context**
None

items.title: Accessing headerDict throws AttributeError

labels.name: Fixed?
labels.description: We believe this issue has been fixed. If still open, we are awaiting confirmation from issue creator

items.body:
In order to get your bug addressed in a timely manner, or at all :smiley:, please fill out the below bug report. Please try to make it as easy as possible for us to understand what is going on. We may close out any bugs or issues without warning that are not complete or coherent.

In the bug template below anything is [square brackets] should be filled out or removed if the item doesn't apply.

Should you encounter an error that has not already been reported, please do the following when reporting it:
**Bug Metadata**
* - [x] Using latest supported version of extract_msg **version 0.25.1**
* Your python version: **Python 3.7.5**
* How did you launch extract_msg?
  - [ ] My command line or
  - [x] I used the extract_msg package

**Describe the bug**
When trying to reference a message's `headerDict` attribute, an AttributeError is raised.

[ If applicable ]
**What code did you use or can we use to reproduce this error?

```python
import extract_msg
m = extract_msg.openMsg("test.msg")
m.headerDict
```

Is there a message.msg file you want to share to help us reproduce this? **No**
- [ ] Uploaded message (drag and drop on this window)
- [ ] Emailed message as an attachment to admins: [Enter Subject Line Here]

**Traceback**
```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
/tmp/msg-extractor/extract_msg/message.py in headerDict(self)
    385         try:
--> 386             return self._headerDict
    387         except AttributeError:

AttributeError: 'Message' object has no attribute '_headerDict'

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-4-a0e9f0865b1d> in <module>
      1 import extract_msg
      2 m = extract_msg.openMsg("test.msg")
----> 3 m.headerDict

/tmp/msg-extractor/extract_msg/message.py in headerDict(self)
    386             return self._headerDict
    387         except AttributeError:
--> 388             self._headerDict = dict(self.header._header)
    389             self._headerDict.pop('Received')
    390             return self._headerDict

AttributeError: 'Message' object has no attribute '_header'
```

**Screenshots**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8660252/87256808-6132ab00-c45b-11ea-93f2-37192cd7a4cd.png)


**Additional context**

In `msg-extractor/extract_msg/message.py`, changing line 388 from:

```python
self._headerDict = dict(self.header._header)
```

to

```python
self._headerDict = dict(self.header._headers)
```

worked for me:

```bash
git clone https://github.com/mattgwwalker/msg-extractor.git
cd msg-extractor

egrep header._header extract_msg/message.py
sed -i "s/header._header/header._headers/" extract_msg/message.py
egrep header._header extract_msg/message.py

python setup.py install
```

items.title: AttributeError: 'Namespace' object has no attribute 'html'

labels.name: Fixed?
labels.description: We believe this issue has been fixed. If still open, we are awaiting confirmation from issue creator

items.body:
**Bug Metadata**
* extract-msg-0.25.0
* Python 3.7.0 (v3.7.0:1bf9cc5093, Jun 27 2018, 04:59:51) [MSC v.1914 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32
* How did you launch extract_msg?
  - From command line at the directory where the .msg file is.

**Describe the bug**
I have just installed your library with:
pip install git+https://github.com/mattgwwalker/msg-extractor

And  going to the directory where the .msg is I have executed the following comand from a Powershell as per your project documentation:
 python -m extract_msg .\MensajeAbrebien.msg

The file "MensajeAbrebien.msg" is a .msg file that can be opened double clicking on it and it show information in my Outlook client.

**What code did you use or can we use to reproduce this error?

```
PS C:\temp> python -m extract_msg .\MensajeAbrebien.msg
Error with file '.\MensajeAbrebien.msg': Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Python37pro\lib\site-packages\extract_msg\__main__.py", line 47, in <module>
    msg.save(toJson = args.json, useFileName = args.use_filename, ContentId = args.cid, html = args.html, rtf = args.html)
AttributeError: 'Namespace' object has no attribute 'html'
```

Is there a message.msg file you want to share to help us reproduce this?

Due to my company policies I can't upload that file here, I will only upload screenshots shadowing company info

**Traceback**

**Screenshots**
The .msg file opened in Outlook client:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14201057/86220082-5aff1d80-bb83-11ea-82a5-2f73de07363e.png)

**Additional context**
As I say the .msg file opens OK with an Outlook client, but trying to automate and extract the attachments and the email body I can't progress using your library. Any help would be appreciated. Thanks in advance!

items.title: Deprecation warning due to invalid escape sequences

labels.name: Nearly Fixed
labels.description: This issue has nearly been fixed, and the fix will likely be coming within the next few days

items.body:
**Bug Metadata**
* - [x] Using latest supported version of extract_msg
* Your python version: Python 3.8
* How did you launch extract_msg?
  - [ ] My command line or
  - [ ] I used the extract_msg package

**Describe the bug**

Deprecation warnings are raised due to invalid escape sequences. This can be fixed by using raw strings or escaping the literals. pyupgrade also helps in automatic conversion : https://github.com/asottile/pyupgrade/

```
find . -iname '*.py' | xargs -P4 -I{} python3.8 -Wall -m py_compile {}
./setup.py:17: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \.
  version_re = re.compile("__version__ = '(?P<version>[0-9\.]*)'")
```

items.title: UnicodeDecodeError saving outlook msg
items.body:
**Bug Metadata**
* - [x] Using latest supported version of extract_msg
* Your python version: Python 3.7.3
* How did you launch extract_msg?
  - [x] I used the extract_msg package

**Describe the bug**
UnicodeDecode error when saving emails with emoji's in the message body, for example "\U0001f60a" or "\U0001F609". See attached for example MSG file.  

[ If applicable ]
**What code did you use or can we use to reproduce this error?
```
import extract_msg
msg = extract_msg.Message("hello_unicode.msg")
msg.save()
``` 

Is there a message.msg file you want to share to help us reproduce this?
- [x] Uploaded message (drag and drop on this window)

[hello_unicode.zip](https://github.com/mattgwwalker/msg-extractor/files/4504643/hello_unicode.zip)

**Traceback**
```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
UnicodeEncodeError                        Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-1-255ae0c441a8> in <module>
      1 import extract_msg
      2 msg = extract_msg.Message("hello_unicode.msg")
----> 3 msg.save()

~\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\extract_msg\message.py in save(self, toJson, useFileName, raw, ContentId, customPath, customFilename)
    614                 f.write('Date: ' + xstr(self.date) + self.__crlf)
    615                 f.write('-----------------' + self.__crlf + self.__crlf)
--> 616                 f.write(self.body)
    617 
    618             f.close()

~\Anaconda3\lib\encodings\cp1252.py in encode(self, input, final)
     17 class IncrementalEncoder(codecs.IncrementalEncoder):
     18     def encode(self, input, final=False):
---> 19         return codecs.charmap_encode(input,self.errors,encoding_table)[0]
     20 
     21 class IncrementalDecoder(codecs.IncrementalDecoder):

UnicodeEncodeError: 'charmap' codec can't encode character '\U0001f60a' in position 14: character maps to <undefined>
```

**Additional context**
I solved it for my project by removing non-ascii chars,  changing line 616 in message.py to:
```
f.write(self.body.encode('ascii', 'ignore'))
``` 
Is there a better way to deal with this? Also, the JSON dump ensures ascii by default, would be nice if there is a fallback in place when these characters are present when saving to text

Thanks for this library, really helpful!

items.title: Support UTF encoding, not just ASCII (Encoding bug)

labels.name: Fixed?
labels.description: We believe this issue has been fixed. If still open, we are awaiting confirmation from issue creator

items.body:
Should you encounter an error that has not already been reported, please do the following when reporting it:
**Bug Metadata**
* - [x] Using latest supported version of extract_msg
* Your python version: Python [3.6.4]
* How did you launch extract_msg?
  - [x] My command line or
  - [x] I used the extract_msg package
(it happens in both)

**Describe the bug**
See the fix commit in my fork: https://github.com/patham9/msg-extractor/commit/5f7058ff6576a6303a6844a0d579b0f1af6b24bc
By default ASCII encoding is used when open is called, now imagine the msg file contains a unicode character. What will happen? This library is deemed to crash.

[ If applicable ]
**What code did you use or can we use to reproduce this error?

```
Message("name.msg")
or
python3.6 -m extract_msg server.msg
with a file containing at least one unicode (non-ASCII) character.
```

Is there a message.msg file you want to share to help us reproduce this?
Sorry I cannot do so but I'm sure you can create a msg file with a unicode-encoded character in it yourself.

**Traceback**
```
Error with file 'name.msg': Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/extract_msg/__main__.py", line 47, in <module>
    msg.save(toJson = args.json, useFileName = args.use_filename, ContentId = args.cid)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/extract_msg/message.py", line 616, in save
    f.write(self.body)
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character '\u2019' in position 75: ordinal not in range(128)
```

items.title: Time zone bug
items.body:
Should you encounter an error that has not already been reported, please do the following when reporting it:
**Bug Metadata**
* - [x] Using latest supported version of extract_msg
* Your python version: Python [3.6.4]
* How did you launch extract_msg?
  - [x] My command line or
  - [x] I used the extract_msg package 
(it happens in both)

**Describe the bug**
See the fix commit in my fork: https://github.com/patham9/msg-extractor/commit/5f7058ff6576a6303a6844a0d579b0f1af6b24bc
pytz library only works on some Linux distributions. On many smaller distributions time zone info might not be available, and even if they have it, pytz library does not correctly query it (on Corepure64 9.0), leading to the error message that time zone info is missing. I see that it is an issue in pytz, but you may also re-consider if this dependency should be referenced at all given its secondary role. In my fix I simply didn't use the library and got correct output.

[ If applicable ]
**What code did you use or can we use to reproduce this error?

```
Message("name.msg")
or
python3.6 -m extract_msg server.msg
```

Is there a message.msg file you want to share to help us reproduce this?
This bug does not depend on any specific msg file.

**Traceback**
```
 File "test.py", line 2, in <module>
    Message("/home/tc/name.msg")
 File "/home/tc/msg-extractor/extract_msg/message.py", line 87, in __init__
    self.header
  File "/home/tc/msg-extractor/extract_msg/message.py", line 219, in header
    header.add_header('Date', self.date)
  File "/home/tc/msg-extractor/extract_msg/message.py", line 272, in date
    self._date = self._prop.date
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/extract_msg/properties.py", line 123, in date
    self.__date = fromTimeStamp(msgEpoch(self.get('00390040').value)).__format__(
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/extract_msg/utils.py", line 123, in fromTimeStamp
    return datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(stamp, tzlocal.get_localzone())
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tzlocal/unix.py", line 131, in get_localzone
    _cache_tz = _get_localzone()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/tzlocal/unix.py", line 125, in _get_localzone
    raise pytz.UnknownTimeZoneError('Can not find any timezone configuration')
```

items.title: Add option to se stringEncoding explicitly
items.body: I've encountered issue with malformed .msg files containing bad encoding property. Therefore it would be nice to have an option to set the stringEncoding explicitly.

items.title: How can I retrieve the attachment type / extension in real-time?
items.body:
How can I retrieve the attachment type / extension in real-time?
I've tried to use attachment.type, but it only returns 'data' which is not what I expected. 
Is there a way to do so instead of saving the attachments then read their extension names?

labels.name: Complete
labels.description: This feature has been fully implemented.

items.body: How can I check if a message is read or unread? (if it is possible)

items.title: Is the offset for In-Reply-To, References headers known?
items.body: We would love to be able to reconstruct email message threads from .msg files. While this brilliant parser already has support for the `Message-ID` header, I haven't seen reference to the `In-Reply-To` and `References` headers, which form its counterpart. This would be necesary in order to re-construct full message chains.

items.title: Set fallback encoding for message strings
items.body:
My proposal is to return a fallback encoding when a message does not specify any encoding; and to log a warning alongside. Here is the stack trace we're seeing:

```
File "/ingestors/ingestors/manager.py", line 120, in ingest_entity
    self.ingest(file_path, entity)
  File "/ingestors/ingestors/manager.py", line 133, in ingest
    self.delegate(ingestor_class, file_path, entity)
  File "/ingestors/ingestors/manager.py", line 147, in delegate
    ingestor_class(self).ingest(file_path, entity)
  File "/ingestors/ingestors/email/outlookmsg.py", line 37, in ingest
    msg = FieldMessage(file_path)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/extract_msg/message.py", line 87, in __init__
    self.header
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/extract_msg/message.py", line 212, in header
    headerText = self._getStringStream('__substg1.0_007D')
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/extract_msg/message.py", line 166, in _getStringStream
    return None if tmp is None else tmp.decode(self.stringEncoding)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/dist-packages/extract_msg/message.py", line 292, in stringEncoding
    raise Exception('Encoding property not found')
Exception: Encoding property not found
```

Unfortunately, I cannot share the files causing this (they are subject to an active journalistic investigation). But it is reasonable to assume that they might not originate from Microsoft Outlook (instead, e.g., an eDiscovery tool), or have been tampered with.

items.title: building on windows for python 3.5+
items.body:
I'm getting the following issue when building on windows for python 3.6 cloned the repo, and ran `python setup.py install`, which yielded the following error: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15128391/61002415-7ef0a000-a32f-11e9-8463-f6aa66c08b09.png) It appears to be related to issues with a character in the readme, which is read in the setup.py file. Because encoding isn't set, I believe it's defaulting to system default cp1252, which is causing the issue. I added a few lines to the setup.py script to deal with this and it built fine: 
# read in the description from README
if os.name=='nt' and sys.version_info[0] >= 3:
    with open("README.rst", encoding='utf-8') as stream:
        long_description = stream.read()
else:
    with open("README.rst") as stream:
        long_description = stream.read()

items.body:
Should you encounter an error that has not already been reported, please do the following when reporting it:
**Bug Metadata**
* Using extract_msg-0.22.0
* Your python version: Python 3.6.4
* How did you launch extract_msg?

**Describe the bug**
the --raw option as listed in the read me does not appear to be a valid option.

 python3 -m extract_msg --raw Aw_Rech_M69G10L.msg
usage: extract_msg [-h] [--use-content-id] [--dev] [--validate] [--json]
                   [--file-logging] [--verbose] [--log LOG]
                   [--config CONFIG_PATH] [--out OUT_PATH] [--use-filename]
                   msg [msg ...]
extract_msg: error: unrecognized arguments: --raw

and:

 python3 -m extract_msg -h
usage: extract_msg [-h] [--use-content-id] [--dev] [--validate] [--json]
                   [--file-logging] [--verbose] [--log LOG]
                   [--config CONFIG_PATH] [--out OUT_PATH] [--use-filename]
                   msg [msg ...]

extract_msg: Extracts emails and attachments saved in Microsoft Outlook's .msg
files. https://github.com/mattgwwalker/msg-extractor

positional arguments:
  msg                   An msg file to be parsed

optional arguments:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  --use-content-id, --cid
                        Save attachments by their Content ID, if they have
                        one. Useful when working with the HTML body.
  --dev                 Changes to use developer mode. Automatically enables
                        the --verbose flag. Takes precedence over the
                        --validate flag.
  --validate            Turns on file validation mode. Turns off regular file
                        output.
  --json                Changes to write output files as json.
  --file-logging        Enables file logging.
  --verbose             Turns on console logging. Implies --verbose
  --log LOG             Set the path to write the file log to.
  --config CONFIG_PATH  Set the path to load the logging config from.
  --out OUT_PATH        Set the folder to use for the program output.
                        (Default: Current directory)
  --use-filename        Sets whether the name of each output is based on the
                        msg filename.

items.body:
Hi, 

I tried extracting text from .msg files generated from readpst (https://linux.die.net/man/1/readpst) but it ends up in errors. 
I ran the following command on my pst export 
```
readpst -o ./msgs -D -r -te -S -m abc.pst
```
And when I run extract_msg on the .msg files  generated in the previous step, I get the following error
```
$ python extract_msg/  -i xyz.msg -p . -u
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/runpy.py", line 162, in _run_module_as_main

  File "extract_msg/recipient.py", line 17, in __init__

AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'encode'
```

Does anyone know how to resolve this issue?

Akshat

items.title: Extracted date shows timezone in a non-RFC2822 format
items.body:
**Bug Metadata**
* - [X] Using latest supported version of extract_msg
* Your python version: Python [3.7.2]
* How did you launch extract_msg?
  - [ ] My command line or
  - [X] I used the extract_msg package

**Describe the bug**
The timezone of the date that gets put in the Message.date property isn't RFC2822 formatted.
It is formatted as:
```Mon, 18 Nov 2013 09:26:24 GMT +0100```

The standard describes the format as:
```Mon, 18 Nov 2013 09:26:24 +0100```
So without the GMT.

The problem arises when the date is parsed using the email.utils.parsedate_to_datetime function, which takes timezones into account:

```
In [14]: email.utils.parsedate_to_datetime('Mon, 18 Nov 2013 09:26:24 GMT +0100')
Out[14]: datetime.datetime(2013, 11, 18, 9, 26, 24, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)

In [15]: email.utils.parsedate_to_datetime('Mon, 18 Nov 2013 09:26:24 +0100')
Out[15]: datetime.datetime(2013, 11, 18, 9, 26, 24, tzinfo=datetime.timezone(datetime.timedelta(seconds=3600)))
```

I'm not sure if this is a problem in msg-extractor or in the way it's stored in the msg file. However, if I open the msg file in Outlook on a Windows environment, it shows the Date header as follows:
```Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2013 10:26:24 +0200```

items.title: Enforce unicode in os functions
items.body:
Paths with Unicode characters will return as '??' in some versions of python, which is not acceptable to things that use a path to find anything. 

How: Add os compatibility module that ensures the functions we are using will return Unicode.

items.title: pypi module naming
items.body:
Currently the setup.py calls this package ExtractMsg.

Based on the [package naming convention in PEP0008](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#package-and-module-names), I want to suggest the name is either changed to msg_extractor or extract_msg.

If you all agree, which do you prefer?

the iteritems() function is used which is deprecated in python3. I discovered this when trying to use the tests in python3. 

My question is, does py3 invocation not hit this code? And the tests do? Or is this a bug?

items.title: Message constructor no longer supports StringIO datastream
items.body:
According to the README the Message constructor should support a datastream. In 0.3 it did actually support this. In 0.17 no longer for StringIO. The culprit is in line 567 where the len of the path argument (the first argument, that could) is checked. Of course a StringIO object has no __len__ attribute, so this fails.
```
  File "/home/odorboprd11/odoo/parts/runbot/runbot/static/build/05694-10-0-import-development-dc9dd7/parts/odoo/odoo/addons/mail_drop_target/models/mail_thread.py", line 26, in message_process_msg
    message_msg = Message(StringIO(b64decode(message)))
  File "/home/odorboprd11/odoo/parts/runbot/runbot/static/build/05694-10-0-import-development-dc9dd7/eggs/ExtractMsg-0.17-py2.7.egg/ExtractMsg.py", line 657, in __init__
    elif len(path) < 1536:
AttributeError: StringIO instance has no attribute '__len__'
```

Maybe test wether path argument actually has a len()/__len__ attribute, or just put it in a try/except block.

items.title: Project updates
items.body:
Given that it has been 9 months since this has been updated by you, and that several issues and pull requests have been opened in that time, I would like to suggest the recruitment of additional collaborators. 

I personally would be very willing to help do this, and have been managing this project as much as a regular user can for a while. I've made my own pull request that combines the features of several of the pull requests and adds even more. Also, my pull request would be able to close several different currently opened issues.

Another qualifying point is that I am VERY familiar with the msg file type, and have been working with it for a little over a year now.

Please consider my offer, and thank you for your time.

- The Elemental of Creation

items.title: [Request] Add property for extracting compressed rtf data from the msg file
Turn msg-extractor into an actual Python package
items.body:
Currently the recommended way to install this lib is via GIT and there's
no tarball on PYPI. This has different drawbacks:

- it is slow to download compared to a HTTP fetch from the PYPI repo
- it is error prone when it comes to pin a specific revision/cset in
requirements.txt (e.g. git+
https://github.com/mattgwwalker/msg-extractor.git@2a24c9950d34932ed5979693cb70d758d78715df#egg=ExtractMsg)
- e.g. I didn't understand why I coulndn't import ExtractMsg and it was
because I add to append #egg=ExtractMsg in requirements.txt
- a GIT url cannot be used as a install_requires=... dependency in
setup.py so you have to necessarily use pip + requirements.txt.
- relying on requirements.txt means that if package A depends from
msg-extractor and packages B and C depend from package A you'll have
to put msg-extractor in all 3 requirements.txt of pkg A, B and C
(whereas with setup.py you would only set it in setup.py of A)

Basically right now msg-extractor is a Python script hosted on github.
Instead it should benefit if it were aa standard Python package hosted on
PYPI.

Practical proposal:

- provide a setup.py, set package name to msgextractor for PEP8
compliance
- rename MsgExtractor.py to msgextractor.py
- API usage would be:

from msgextractor import Message
m = Message(...)

- cmdline usage would be

python -m msgextractor example.msg

If this is acceptable I can provide a PR.

items.title: Python 3 support broken
items.body:
A recent commit broke Python 3 support.
https://github.com/mattgwwalker/msg-extractor/commit/00c438ea07299a9e5b29f9de9225e257dfcfb00a#commitcomment-26740979

items.title: Provide a PYPI package
items.body:
Currently the designated way to install msg-extractor is via GIT. There is no tarball on PYPI. This has different drawbacks:

- It is slow to download compared to a plain HTTP fetch from the official PYPI repo
- It is error prone when it comes to pin a specific revision/cset in requirements.txt (e.g. `git+https://github.com/mattgwwalker/msg-extractor.git@2a24c9950d34932ed5979693cb70d758d78715df#egg=ExtractMsg`). It took me a while to understand I couldn't `import ExtractMsg` because I had to append `#egg=ExtractMsg` in requirements.txt.
- a GIT url cannot be used as a `install_requires=...` dependency in setup.py so you have to necessarily use pip + requirements.txt.
- relying on requirements.txt means that if package A depends from msg-extractor and packages B and C depend from package A you'll have to put msg-extractor in all 3 requirements.txt of pkg A, B and C (whereas with setup.py you would only set it in setup.py of A). This is currently the major annoyance for us.

If this is desirable I can provide a PR to ease up this process (e.g. via Makefile + [.pypirc](https://docs.python.org/2/distutils/packageindex.html#pypirc)).

EDIT - here's a PR which paves the way to PYPI upload + unit tests: https://github.com/mattgwwalker/msg-extractor/pull/26

items.title: Merge request
items.body: I made a number of improvements to the ExtractMsg.py script.  I tried submitting a merge/pull request with my changes (two actually) but not sure if I did it right.  Haven't used git before.  If it doesn't work let me know.  Thanks.

items.title: No Output
items.body: Hi! I am new to python. I installed this library using pip and executed it as per the readme file. I did not get any output. The script executes without any error. Am I doing something wrong? Please help me with this.

items.title: Handle .msg files having .eml files as attachment
items.body:
How to handle the case when stream tag 37010102 is missing from the attachment storage. There is a storage with a tag 3701000D present in the attachment storage which again contains an attachment of .eml extension.
Can we save the attachment of the .msg file in which stream tag 37010102 is missing but tag 3701000D is present or having .msg or .eml as attachment.

items.title: "NameError : name 'filename' not found" when setting useFileName=True
items.body:
Hello,

It seems that when setting the parameter useFileName=True in the Message.save function, it returns a NameError : "filename is not defined".
After checking in the ExtractMsg.py code, I don't see where the filename attribute is defined for the Message class. Am I the only one to get this error ?

I am using an Anaconda with python 3.5.
Best regards

items.title: Email Headers
items.body:
I'm interested in using this to extract various properties from email headers such as authentication results, sender IP, etc.

Is any further development planned along these lines, or would I be on my own with this?

EDIT: Nevermind, I realized this information is accessible already via the .header property of the message.

items.title: line 542, in <module>  msg.save(toJson, useFileName
items.body:
The errors are as follows: (latest extractmsg.py btw)

$ python /usr/bin/ExtractMSG.py testemail-unicode-rtf.msg
Error with file 'testemail-unicode-rtf.msg': Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/ExtractMSG.py", line 542, in <module>
    msg.save(toJson, useFileName)
  File "/usr/bin/ExtractMSG.py", line 413, in save
    attachmentNames.append(attachment.save())
  File "/usr/bin/ExtractMSG.py", line 193, in save
    f.write(self.data)
TypeError: argument 1 must be string or buffer, not None

Same for all the other msg's I've attached. Outlook version 2007 fully patched.
I get the same with 2010 msg's as well. The errors are also present when using --raw as well. 
[testemails.zip](https://github.com/mattgwwalker/msg-extractor/files/630966/testemails.zip)

items.title: Question: Outlook for OSX
items.body: Can this be used with Outlook for Mac formatted messages? Those files appear to have an extension of ".olk15Message" rather than ".msg". I could certainly just try it out, or read through the code, but thought I'd ask anyway.

items.title: using as module
items.body:
hi. your script works perfectly for me. but i want to use it as a module. and i cant get my head around doing that. if i use something like

``` python
from ExtactMsg import Message
msg = Message('foo.msg')
msg.save()
```

i get

``` python
    def save(self, raw=False):

>       if useFileName:
E       NameError: name 'useFileName' is not defined

```

in gets defined if i run the script in a standalone way but not if i just want to use the class. even

``` python
from ExtactMsg import Message
useFileName = False
msg = Message('foo.msg')
msg.save()
```

does work for me. i thought i understand something from python but i dont know how i can define that variable to use the class. maybe someone can help.

items.title: Python 3.5 Support?
items.body: What needs to be done to update this to Python 3.5 support? Thanks for the great library!

items.title: UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii'
items.body:
I can't provide the original message but there is an attached PDF in the email, its a quote for the company I work for. Is there some missing escaping? Is my .msg file not in the right ascii format? Have you seen this issue before?

Codec can't encode character u'\u2019' in position 4536: ordinal not in range(128)

``` python
Error with file '/Users/myself/Desktop/quote.msg': Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "ExtractMsg.py", line 497, in <module>
    msg.save()
  File "ExtractMsg.py", line 402, in save
    f.write(self.body)
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\u2019' in position 4536: ordinal not in range(128)
```
